reviewText:
I played Slammed on mobile, loved it so much I bought it again on a device that I can actually read reliably, and then quickly took to a review to extoll its virtues.

Slammed has your character rise from an no-name indie star to the top match at the biggest PPV at the biggest professional promotion. The story is written with heart and charm and genuine love of wrestling. With a brilliant little cheat on the part of the author (Matches are sometimes real and sometimes scripted), you have a game where everything can be on the line in a fight, and in another situation you might meet the aging veteran who never had the push he deserved or the tacky, unprofessional wrestler who takes issue with the booking. This could have ended up being a disastrous attempt to merge both the magic of kayfabe and the grit behind the curtain, but the writer pulls it off wonderfully.

Even better, there aren't just several endings, there are at least three different whole final scenarios depending on your choices, a few secret endings here and there, multiple romances to pursue, there is some replayability here.

I only have a couple of complaints about the game and they both stem from it being a standard Choice of Games game. First, there are no save slots. Pure auto-save. There are good branching scenarios throughout the whole game so replaying is not a pain, but several ending variants are determined entirely by your actions in the last three or so chapters. There are not many dead ends but you can lose the big matches and have to replay the whole story for a less unsatisfying ending. (Fairly quick if you have read it all before, thankfully.)

Second, Choice of Games shoehorns in their pet device where you can be any sex and pursue any sex, but these games are not Mass Effect in which you can lard up the game with a dozen cheesy romances of every orientation. The result is characters get gender bent and FEEL gender bent if you pick an unnatural (respective to the writing) orientation. Slammed does pull this off better than other Choice of Games games. The womens league wrestlers all get their own descriptions so even the ones that perform the same role as they would for a male player character still feel like their own characters and there is a really cute story path that is appropriately open only to female characters. But there's one specific love interest in Slammed who is either a charming feminine woman or a kinda weird feminine man. It's a small complaint overall though.

Even then, you'll probably miss a lot of references and easter eggs if you are not familiar with how american indie federations work because it's not just two guys pretending to punch each others in underwear"

reviewText:
Just the concept of kayfabe as a stat and a mechanic is amazing, and it works great here. The writing is solid all around, and it's worth noting that it attempts to be accessible to non-wresting aficionados too by providing little explanations of wrestling lingo at times, though it's probably not quite enough for the entirely uninitiated. Keep your search engine of choice at the ready if that is the case for you, and you'll be a-okay.

It branches plenty, about as much as you'd expect from a Choice of game. If I was left wanting more, it is more a testament to the quality of the game (and my fascination with the sport, to be perfectly fair) than a judgement on how much content there is.

Very much recommended; it's the wrestling adventure most savvy fans dream of, and unique in what it does to the genre. I wish traditional" wrestling games were more like this."

reviewText:
I bought Slammed! when it originally released as one of my first COGs, and have played it many times since then, so  I’m happy to see it finally get its day in the spotlight here on steam, as it is one of the best titles they have published to date.

I know a lot of you probably aren’t wrasslin’ fans, and you don’t have to be. If you enjoy interactive fiction, you’ll still find a great story with interesting characters and a TON of character choice and different routes for replayability.

For those of you that are or have been fans, however,  you have the added bonus of enjoying loads of in-jokes and references that will make you smile – maybe even a few laugh out loud moments too – and have fun matching the game’s characters to the people they are actually based on. It’s always nice when a writer has such a grasp on and love for the material he is writing as the game’s quality can only be strengthened by it. Not only is it a great read, but it is a fictionalized walk through memory lane. (It is kind of sad to play as a female wrestler, though, as the fictional divas division is certainly better handled than the real one :p )

Tldr; Slammed is a lengthy CYOA of rising to fame in the GWA. There are many ways to make it, and more than a few ways to fail; do your skills have what it takes to make you the next HBK or Stone Cold?

I wanted to refund this game so bad at first, but I realised because I was playing a character I knew wasn't me was central to the experience of pro-wrestling. I'm not an active fan but this made me want to return to my childhood days and enjoy it all.

This game was made by a master of terminology and theory of the genre. I played a heel through almost the whole game and just twice I broke kayfabe, once to sign a fan an autograph [if they said I was a jerk about it haha, I was nice to them.] and also to a woman who had some problem with family or something.

This is a great story and I only played once. It certainly levels with the standard highest bar I place for CoG, which is Choice of Robots [my fave story wise and sheer yes you can do that

reviewText: A fun little text based game that is well worth the money.  It's by no means perfect especially the no-win set up ith JJ early in the game but after that there seems to be a lot of fun variations to choose from.  I played as a complete self centered womansier who would do anything to get what he wanted and then as totally honourable lesbian who became the champion of the world and got the girl of her dreams and both times had a ball.  A decent number of acheivements to be had means it's probably got a fair amount of replayability for a text game too.  It's pretty sad when this was 10x more fun than 2k's recent wwe15.

reviewText: Slammed does something I’ve never seen in a wrestling game before, and that’s explore the gritty viper’s nest of politics that the professional wrestling industry often is. The author is very clearly a passionate fan of pro wrestling, and shows a deep knowledge of how the industry works. Even if you don’t like wrestling, you’ll like Slammed if you’re a fan of Interactive Fiction. The game explains what you need to know about pro wrestling as it goes along, and has a great story that incorporates your choices and what kind of wrestler your character is. Without giving too much away, the moral dilemma near the end that sets up which final route you take was awesome and chilling. I played through this twice, and even on the second playthrough I couldn’t do what I would’ve had to do to get my championship match, and I’m okay with that.

reviewText:
As a die hard wrestling fan, this grabbed my attention immedietly. Although I was initially skeptical of how the wrestling industry might be represented, I found myself drawn in to a story that is gripping, entertaining, and although it requires more than a little suspension of disbelief, drew out real emotion reaction from me.

Just like the real thing.

As much as I think at least some familiarity or interest with wrestling will be required to get full enjoyment from this game, the storyline and the replayability of making different choices still might be enough to tempt outsiders to give it a try for such a low price tag. If you ARE a wrestling fan, then....buy it? What are you reading this for? Buy it now.

Have you bought it? Good.

Having been a fan of games of this sort for some time, I'm pleased to see the genre branching out into other themes. The Heroes Rise series made me a fan, but Slammed has made me an enthusiast.

reviewText: This is one of the better written interactive novels. Slammed takes you into the seedy side of 'professional' wrestling and does a nice job of delivering you an experience while still letting you make decisions within the framework of the story. I've only completed one play through so I'm not sure how interesting it would be to play again but I can see how things could branch into different directions. Especially if you wanted to play a 'Heel'. If you are at all interested and enjoy the genre then I give this a high recommendation.

reviewText:
I'm not a fan of wrestling.

Yet somehow, somwhere along the line of playting the demo to this I ended up in love. Paolo Chikiamco is a master of terminology and theory, making every small detail easily understood with the depth required to the uninitiated. I was surprised as I went on at the build-up and the falls, the pacing the best out of any Choice of Games title I've played so far. Each of the choices, the differences in the story, they all add their own flair and style which alone doesn't mean much but when it's all together you really feel like you've crafted a unique persona with their own moveset, motivations, public avatar and fleshed-out motivations.

Lengthy without feeling bloated, I would reccommend this to anyone, wrestling fanatic or not. It's that great.

reviewText: Slammed! is an interactive story based in the world of professional wrestling. You don't need to know or understand professional wrestling, although some terms are crucial to understand (ie, the concept of kayfabe) and a quick google search every now and then will help as you go along. At its core though, this is a story about your journey and the personalities that you interactive with - the wrestling is the backdrop for the most part.\n\nThe story's pacing is excellent, and the blurring of the line between real and kayfabe (which is broadly the same concept as the fourth wall" in acting) is really well done. The quality of the writing
date: purely from the point of view of the storytelling
hoursPlayed: the best example of this is the section that features the "promotional video" for the grand finale
voteText: where the writing got me genuinely pumped up for the big climax.\n\nThere is a reasonable amount of replayability - there are enough branching story arcs for you to play several times and not get bored of it. The choices feel meaningful
helpfulPercent: and there are several possible finales and many different journeys you can take on the way to them.\n\nHighly recommended."

reviewText:
Fantastic interactive novel with an abundance of meaningful choices.  Once I started, I couldn't put it down.  (I didn't play 24 hours in a row, mind.  I left the game running while I slept, ate, etc., hence the playtime.)

You *don't* have to be a wrestling fan to enjoy the novel.  While I've had acquaintances who were into it, I only had a passing awareness of it, and still had a great time with the story.  The characters are well written, and the tale's highs and lows pack an emotional punch.

Highly recommended.

reviewText: I usually don't go in for stuff like this, but am I ever glad that I did. Slammed is an interactive novel in the vain of choose your own adventure in which you assume the role of a pro wrestler. I had luke warm expectations for this going in. I guess I assumed that it would read like wrestling fan fiction, which I'm sure exists but have absolutely no interest in persuing. Instead, I was treated to an interactive adventure full of colorful characters, twists and turns that had me up late into the wee hours. I will definitely run through again to see what the alternate choices could have lead to. This totally exceeded my expectations and has me hungry for more.

reviewText: If you have any interest in wrestling there's a great chance you will enjoy this game immensely. In my opinion the best Choose your own adventure book I have ever played, once I started I wanted to know how the story unfolds - even if that meant sacrificing a night's sleep. And I don't regret a second as this had me captivated throughout. Moreover you get the impression that your decisions carry real weight - and the fact that I only got about a quarter of all possible achievements supports that conclusion. With an average duration of one playthrough of 4-6 hours there's only one thing left to say about Slammed: A Winner Is You (to quote an old NES wrestling game)

reviewText:
I may be biased due to my love for professional wrestling and the WWE in general, but this is by far the best CYOA I've ever experienced.

Play every match the way you're told, or make it a shoot.
Become the face of the federation, and gain the adoration of the crowd. Play the heel and have everyone rooting against you. Or hell, be a silent masked man taking the federation by storm.

Be on a reality television show featuring wrestlers and pop stars!

Romance! Drama! Hate! Love!

Who knew the best way to make a wrestling game was for there to be no traditional gameplay at all?
